TITLE I--DRUG COURTS

SEC. 101. GRANT AUTHORITY. The Attorney General can provide grants for programs involving judicial supervision over non-violent offenders with substance abuse issues, along with integrated sanctions and services like testing, treatment, and supervised release options. The Attorney General can provide grants for programs involving judicial supervision over non-violent offenders with substance abuse issues, integrated sanctions, testing, treatment, and supervised release options. Additionally, programmatic services such as relapse prevention, health care, education, vocational training, job placement, housing placement, and family support services are offered for participants in need. SEC. 102. ADMINISTRATION. The Attorney General consults with relevant officials, may use DOJ components, has regulatory authority to issue guidelines, and sets requirements for grant applications under this title. The proposal for funding must supplement existing sources, identify related initiatives, consult with all affected agencies, have designated judges for supervision, plan for post-Federal support, and describe the evaluation methodology. To request funds under this title, the chief executive or chief justice of a State, local government, or Indian tribal government must submit an application to the Attorney General with required information. The Federal share of a grant may not exceed 75 percent of total costs unless waived by the Attorney General. In-kind contributions can be part of the non-Federal share. The Attorney General ensures equitable geographic distribution of grant awards. Recipients must submit effectiveness reports. Technical assistance, training, and evaluation are provided. SEC. 107. The Attorney General may provide technical assistance, training, and evaluations for programs under this title. These activities can be carried out directly or in collaboration with other entities. SEC. 108 authorizes $200,000,000 for fiscal year 1998 and necessary sums for fiscal years 1999 through 2002. TITLE II focuses on YOUTH COURTS, where the Attorney General runs a program for individuals under 21, requiring parental participation. SEC. 202 authorizes appropriations for this program. SEC. 202 authorizes $50,000,000 for fiscal year 1998 and necessary funds for fiscal years 1999 through 2002 to carry out section 201.
